question: Will the USDA-posted recall by UP Products, LLC, DBA Meyer Wholesale of Ready-To-Eat and Raw Sausage Products issued January 13, 2025 be closed before April 1, 2025?
reasoning:
To assess the probability of the USDA-posted recall by UP Products, LLC being closed before April 1, 2025, I have gathered the following information:

1. **Recall Details**: The recall involves approximately 400 pounds of sausage products due to misbranding and undeclared soy allergen. The products were produced between October 30, 2024, and January 7, 2025. The recall was announced by the USDA's FSIS on January 13, 2025. There have been no confirmed reports of adverse reactions due to consumption of these products. The products were distributed to locations in Michigan and Wisconsin.

2. **Average Duration of Recalls**: Unfortunately, I couldn't find specific data on the average duration of USDA recalls. However, based on general knowledge, the duration of recalls can vary significantly depending on the severity and nature of the issue. Since this recall involves an undeclared allergen, it might be resolved relatively quickly if the issue is straightforward to address.

3. **Current Status**: As of February 27, 2025, there is no specific update indicating that the recall status has changed from Active to Closed. However, the lack of adverse reactions and the nature of the issue (undeclared allergen) suggest that the resolution could be expedited.

Given these factors, I estimate a moderate probability that the recall will be closed before April 1, 2025. The absence of adverse reactions and the straightforward nature of the issue (undeclared allergen) are positive indicators for a timely resolution.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.6

search_results.title: https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage
search_results.content:
---
title: Michigan Company Recalls Hundreds of Pounds of Sausage
url: https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage
hostname: foodmanufacturing.com
description: The products contain undeclared soy.
sitename: Food Manufacturing
date: 2025-01-14
---
WASHINGTON – UP Products LLC, doing business as Meyer Wholesale, of Ewen, Michigan, is recalling approximately 400 pounds of sausage products due to misbranding and an undeclared allergen, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service announced.

The products contain soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product labels.

The ready-to-eat pork and beef Polish sausage and raw pork and beef potato sausage items were produced on various dates from October 30, 2024, through January 7, 2025. The following products are subject to recall:

- 5" x 8" vacuum-sealed packages containing “Otto Meyer's Premium Sausage POLISH SAUSAGE” with lot codes 24304, 24318, 24326, 24346 on a sticker.
- Bulk packed in 12" x 24" clear bags containing “Otto Meyer's Premium Sausage POTATO SAUSAGE” with dates 1/6/25, and 1/7/25 handwritten on the label.

The products subject to recall bear establishment number “EST. M1733” inside the USDA mark of inspection. These items were shipped to a restaurant and retail locations in Michigan, and a retail location in Wisconsin.

The problem was discovered during routine FSIS in-plant verification activities when FSIS personnel observed that soy, a known allergen, was being used as an ingredient and was not declared on the finished product label.

There have been no confirmed reports of adverse reactions due to consumption of these products. Anyone concerned about an illness should contact a healthcare provider.

FSIS is concerned that some product may be in consumer's, retailer's and restaurants' refrigerators or freezers. Restaurants, retailers and consumers who have purchased these products are urged not to serve, sell, or consume them. These products should be thrown away or returned to the place of purchase.

search_results.title: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
search_results.content:
---
title: An Analysis of Food Recalls in the United States, 2002–2023
url: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
hostname: sciencedirect.com
description: This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the pas…
sitename: Journal of Food Protection
date: 2024-12-01
---
Product Contaminants were 91% and Processing Issues 9% of the F&B recalls.

•

All F&B recalls: 53% were Class I, 41% were Class II, and 6% were Class III.

•

Biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of the Class I recalls.

•

Listeria and Salmonella together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

•

Allergens accounted for 28% of the F&B recalls.

Abstract

This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the past 20 years: the database includes over 35,000 recalls. For recall classification purposes, the causes were separated into 2 overall categories consisting of product contaminants or processing issues. The product contaminants category was further separated into 5 groups: allergens, biological contaminants, chemical contaminants, foreign objects, and undeclared food colors. The processing issues category was separated into 6 groups: cGMP issues, HACCP issues, manufacturing issues, mislabeling or misbranding, refrigeration issues, and under-processing. Product contaminants accounted for 91% of the F&B recalls, while processing issues accounted for the remaining 9%. Two groups accounted for about 76% of the recalls: biological contamination and allergens. The FDA classifies recalls by the potential severity of the health impact. Over half of the F&B recalls were Class I recalls, and biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of those recalls. Listeria monocytogenes was the largest cause of all of the recalls accounting for 7,844 recalls: 22% of the total recalls and 45% of the biological contamination recalls. Salmonella serovars were responsible for 6,597 recalls, including 18% of the total recalls and 38% of the biological recalls. Listeria and Salmonella serovars together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

---
WASHINGTON – UP Products LLC, doing business as Meyer Wholesale, of Ewen, Michigan, is recalling approximately 400 pounds of sausage products due to misbranding and an undeclared allergen, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service announced.

The products contain soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product labels.

The ready-to-eat pork and beef Polish sausage and raw pork and beef potato sausage items were produced on various dates from October 30, 2024, through January 7, 2025. The following products are subject to recall:

- 5" x 8" vacuum-sealed packages containing “Otto Meyer's Premium Sausage POLISH SAUSAGE” with lot codes 24304, 24318, 24326, 24346 on a sticker.
- Bulk packed in 12" x 24" clear bags containing “Otto Meyer's Premium Sausage POTATO SAUSAGE” with dates 1/6/25, and 1/7/25 handwritten on the label.

The products subject to recall bear establishment number “EST. M1733” inside the USDA mark of inspection. These items were shipped to a restaurant and retail locations in Michigan, and a retail location in Wisconsin.

The problem was discovered during routine FSIS in-plant verification activities when FSIS personnel observed that soy, a known allergen, was being used as an ingredient and was not declared on the finished product label.

There have been no confirmed reports of adverse reactions due to consumption of these products. Anyone concerned about an illness should contact a healthcare provider.

Restaurants, retailers and consumers who have purchased these products are urged not to serve, sell, or consume them. These products should be thrown away or returned to the place of purchase.

tool_outputs.name: btf_fetch_url_content

content.snippet:
---
title: An Analysis of Food Recalls in the United States, 2002–2023
url: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
hostname: sciencedirect.com
description: This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the pas…
sitename: Journal of Food Protection
date: 2024-12-01
---
Product Contaminants were 91% and Processing Issues 9% of the F&B recalls.

•

All F&B recalls: 53% were Class I, 41% were Class II, and 6% were Class III.

•

Biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of the Class I recalls.

•

Listeria and Salmonella together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

•

Allergens accounted for 28% of the F&B recalls.

Abstract

This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the past 20 years: the database includes over 35,000 recalls. For recall classification purposes, the causes were separated into 2 overall categories consisting of product contaminants or processing issues. The product contaminants category was further separated into 5 groups: allergens, biological contaminants, chemical contaminants, foreign objects, and undeclared food colors. The processing issues category was separated into 6 groups: cGMP issues, HACCP issues, manufacturing issues, mislabeling or misbranding, refrigeration issues, and under-processing. Product contaminants accounted for 91% of the F&B recalls, while processing issues accounted for the remaining 9%. Two groups accounted for about 76% of the recalls: biological contamination and allergens. The FDA classifies recalls by the potential severity of the health impact. Over half of the F&B recalls were Class I recalls, and biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of those recalls. Listeria monocytogenes was the largest cause of all of the recalls accounting for 7,844 recalls: 22% of the total recalls and 45% of the biological contamination recalls. Salmonella serovars were responsible for 6,597 recalls, including 18% of the total recalls and 38% of the biological recalls. Listeria and Salmonella serovars together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

facts.title: https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage
facts.fact: The recall was announced by the USDA's FSIS on January 13, 2025.

facts.title: https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage
facts.fact: There have been no confirmed reports of adverse reactions due to consumption of these products.

facts.title: https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage
facts.fact: The products were distributed to a restaurant and retail locations in Michigan and a retail location in Wisconsin.

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the USDA-posted recall by UP Products, LLC, DBA Meyer Wholesale of Ready-To-Eat and Raw Sausage Products issued January 13, 2025 be closed before April 1, 2025?
Background: [USDA Food Recalls: What You Need to Know](https://www.fda.gov/food/buy-store-serve-safe-food/food-recalls-what-you-need-know)
Resolution criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the status of the recall posted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) is changed from Active to Closed when [this page](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/products-llc-dba-meyer-wholesale-recalls-ready-eat-and-raw-sausage-products-due) is accessed by Metaculus on or after April 1, 2025. If the recall is still shown as Active when the link is accessed by Metaculus, this question resolves as **No**.
Fine print: 
present_date: 2025-02-27T15:45:19.069849


Make sure to use the tools at your disposal to gather relevant information before providing your final probability estimate.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

If the recall is still shown as Active when the link is accessed by Metaculus, this question resolves as **No**.","present_date":"2025-02-27T15:45:19.069849"}

messages.content:
{"url": "https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage", "snippet": "---
title: Michigan Company Recalls Hundreds of Pounds of Sausage
url: https://www.foodmanufacturing.com/recalls-alerts/news/22930519/michigan-company-recalls-hundreds-of-pounds-of-sausage
hostname: foodmanufacturing.com
description: The products contain undeclared soy.
sitename: Food Manufacturing
date: 2025-01-14
---
WASHINGTON – UP Products LLC, doing business as Meyer Wholesale, of Ewen, Michigan, is recalling approximately 400 pounds of sausage products due to misbranding and an undeclared allergen, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service announced.

The products contain soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product labels.

The ready-to-eat pork and beef Polish sausage and raw pork and beef potato sausage items were produced on various dates from October 30, 2024, through January 7, 2025. The following products are subject to recall:

- 5" x 8" vacuum-sealed packages containing “Otto Meyer's Premium Sausage POLISH SAUSAGE” with lot codes 24304, 24318, 24326, 24346 on a sticker.
- Bulk packed in 12" x 24" clear bags containing “Otto Meyer's Premium Sausage POTATO SAUSAGE” with dates 1/6/25, and 1/7/25 handwritten on the label.

The products subject to recall bear establishment number “EST. M1733” inside the USDA mark of inspection. These items were shipped to a restaurant and retail locations in Michigan, and a retail location in Wisconsin.

The problem was discovered during routine FSIS in-plant verification activities when FSIS personnel observed that soy, a known allergen, was being used as an ingredient and was not declared on the finished product label.

There have been no confirmed reports of adverse reactions due to consumption of these products. Anyone concerned about an illness should contact a healthcare provider.

FSIS is concerned that some product may be in consumer's, retailer's and restaurants' refrigerators or freezers. Restaurants, retailers and consumers who have purchased these products are urged not to serve, sell, or consume them. These products should be thrown away or returned to the place of purchase.", "word_count": 303, "snippet_word_count": 303, "snippet_truncated": false, "date_cutoff_start": "2025-01-30T15:45:19.069849", "date_cutoff_end": "2025-02-28T15:45:19.069849", "cached_at": "2025-10-24T05:45:30.314835"}

messages.name: btf_extract_evidence

messages.content:
To assess the probability of the USDA-posted recall by UP Products, LLC being closed before April 1, 2025, I have gathered the following information:

1. **Recall Details**: The recall involves approximately 400 pounds of sausage products due to misbranding and undeclared soy allergen. The products were produced between October 30, 2024, and January 7, 2025. The recall was announced by the USDA's FSIS on January 13, 2025. There have been no confirmed reports of adverse reactions due to consumption of these products. The products were distributed to locations in Michigan and Wisconsin.

2. **Average Duration of Recalls**: Unfortunately, I couldn't find specific data on the average duration of USDA recalls. However, based on general knowledge, the duration of recalls can vary significantly depending on the severity and nature of the issue. Since this recall involves an undeclared allergen, it might be resolved relatively quickly if the issue is straightforward to address.

3. **Current Status**: As of February 27, 2025, there is no specific update indicating that the recall status has changed from Active to Closed. However, the lack of adverse reactions and the nature of the issue (undeclared allergen) suggest that the resolution could be expedited.

Given these factors, I estimate a moderate probability that the recall will be closed before April 1, 2025. The absence of adverse reactions and the straightforward nature of the issue (undeclared allergen) are positive indicators for a timely resolution.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.6
